newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks trend weaker in early trade.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks trend weaker in early trade.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks fell sharply at the start of trading on Wednesday morning, then recovered slightly to trend weak due to a lack of buying incentives and interest rates worries, brokers said.
"Institutions are already pretty overweighted in Hong Kong and it is difficult to see where significant new funds are coming from," said Julian Ings Chambers, associate director at BZW Securities.
The Hang Seng Index was trading 71 points lower at 13,181 on robust turnover of HK$1.96 billion. The index dropped to a low of 13,119.08 at the open.
"There is a growing consensus that rates could rise in March," said Ings-Chambers, referring to the outlook for U.S. interest rates.
Hang Seng Index futures market dipped cautiously at the open, with the March contract falling to a low of 13,055 before recovering.
Uncertainty over the interest rate picture accounted for the choppy performance of U.S. markets, analysts said. The U.S. 30-year long bond closed 13/32 lower to yield 6.85 percent
"There is nothing to push this market up," said Angus Shillington in institutional sales at Asia Equity.
The property sector led the market down, followed by utilities.
Hardest hit were the residential property developers. Cheung Kong was sold off HK$1.50 to trade at HK$72.00 and Henderson Land dropped HK$1.25 to HK$66.25.
New World Development slipped HK$1.00 to HK$43.90.
Hongkong Electric lost HK$0.10 to HK$26.80. The company will lead off the reporting season for the Cheung Kong group on Thursday.
China Light slipped HK$0.40 to HK$35.30 but on thin turnover of only HK$20.6 million.
Red chip CITIC Pacific shed HK$0.80 to HK$38.70 on turnover HK$95.85 million.
Cathay Pacific, which will report 1996 earning later on Wednesday, was trading unchanged at HK$11.95
Shenzhen Expressway which made its debut on Wednesday was the most actively traded stock.
The share,offered at HK$2.20, rose to a high of HK$3.375, then eased to HK$3.05 on heavy turnover of HK$670 million.
